translated: Sutra on the Three Wisdoms
The name of the translator is lost, now attached to the Liang Catalog
The Buddha always wishes to obtain three kinds of people: first, those who have faith; second, those who ask questions; third, those who practice. Some people
only have faith but are not happy, they already have faith but do not wish to practice.
There are three kinds of happiness:
First, not giving;
Second, not practicing precepts;
Third, not concentrating the mind.
One should extinguish thoughts in order to attain the Way, the key lies in non-thought.
Having already extinguished thoughts, form also ceases, and consciousness also ceases.

If the mind has thoughts, this is the four kinds of existence, this is conceptualization - thinking there will be conceptualization, thinking there will be no conceptualization, not being free from conceptualization, being free from conceptualization.
Not transcending conceptualization, one returns to it.
Thinking there will be conceptualization refers to the conceptualization of the Way;
Thinking there will be no conceptualization refers to the conceptualization of formlessness;
Not being free from conceptualization refers to not being free from the conceptualization of meditation practice;
One should depart from thoughts means one should depart from thoughts of birth and death;
Not emerging from thoughts means having no thought of the path, not emerging from the twelve entrances;
Returning to means that when a person is born into the cycle of birth and death, they cannot escape.
The body is likened to the earth, good intentions are like grain, and evil intentions are like weeds.
If one does not remove the weeds and filth, the grain harvest will not be successful;
If a person does not remove evil intentions, they will also not attain the Way.
If a person has anger, it is like the earth giving rise to thorns.
Good intentions are like lightning, coming and then bright, going and then dark again;
Evil thoughts are like clouds covering the sun, when one's own evil intentions arise, one does not see the Way.
Those who study have suffering;
Those who do not study have no suffering.
Those who study have suffering, like a person who plants, first plowing to remove the weeds and filth, then obtaining a large harvest, this is first suffering;
Those who do not learn have no suffering. It is like the earth, if not plowed, will naturally produce thorns and other bad things. This is called having no suffering without learning.
Practicing the Way, first, one can restrain suffering;
second, one can restrain joy;
third, one cannot restrain suffering;
fourth, one cannot restrain joy.
If one can find joy and attain joy, then practice the Way;
if one can find suffering and attain suffering, then practice the Way.
If someone practices the Way and attains suffering, then fears birth and death, and can practice the Way like this, one cannot be given joy.
If someone attains joy and can practice the Way, and their mind is not suffering, like this, one cannot be given suffering.
If someone attains joy and can practice the Way, and attains suffering and can also practice the Way, like this, one can be given joy, but cannot be given suffering.
If someone attains suffering and cannot practice the Way, and attains joy and also cannot practice the Way, like this, one should be given suffering, but cannot be given joy.
There are four kinds of seeking in total:
First, seeking for the sake of the body;
Second, seeking for the sake of vows;
Third, seeking for the sake of delusion;
Fourth, seeking for the sake of practice.
People who wish to preserve their bodies and live long lives are seeking for the sake of the body;
Wishing to obtain nobility, wife, children, and precious treasures is seeking for the sake of vows;
Sacrificing to deities and suppressing evil spirits, wishing to obtain blessings, is seeking for the sake of delusion;
Practicing unwholesome ways, wishing for family peace and attaining the Way, is seeking for the sake of practice.
People have three things that cannot be relied upon:
First, a joyful mind;
Second, wealth and treasures;
Third, human life.
The body can be thought of, and also cannot be thought of;
Considering the body's impurities is thinking of it, but the mind falling into the five desires is not thinking of it.
Goodness can also be thought of, and also cannot be thought of.
It is said that attaining the Way is thinking of it;
What cannot be thought of is said to be, having attained the Way, one should further increase it.
Evil can also be thought of, and also not thought of.
If one repents of one's faults, that is to be thought of;
If one's mind gives rise to falling into evil, that is not to be thought of.
To abandon right mindfulness and take up wrong views is delusion;
To be unable to distinguish right from wrong is doubt.
Evil has two aspects:
One is the basis, the other is the benefit.
What one does is the basis, and receiving the benefits of practice is the benefit. If one removes these, one can attain the Way.
Greed and protection refer to being greedy for what one has already obtained.
Thinking of form is the highest level of greed, because it destroys a single mind. Therefore, protecting greed is attaining the Way, while greed and protection lead to falling into birth and death.
Having already obtained, one further protects, so it is called greed and protection.
To enjoy food means to be joyful.
To think of being full from food means to think of the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment and be satisfied.
To be aware of food means to delight in the Dharma.
Having already followed pain and itching to seek, one further thinks of it as seeking awareness.
All worldly affairs belong to the body, all names belong to the mind, all non-violations belong to precepts, apart from these there is nothing for the Way.
One dharma further destroys the practice of the Way, namely, lack of diligence;
One dharma destroys a person, namely, stinginess and greed.
External evil causes and conditions come to a person, not accepting is forbearance;
One's own evil deeds, not confessing is humiliating oneself.
The past should not be thought of again, the future should not be waited for either, the present should be cut off.
What does not belong to oneself, do not worry about it;
All that has intention is a bondage.
Good intentions should also be forgotten, bad intentions should also be forgotten.
There are three more causes and conditions:
First, not practicing mindfulness;
Second, not frequently contemplating;
Third, not being attached to inverted thoughts.
These three things will not be forgotten again.
From existence one can attain non-existence, existence cannot attain existence, this is called the meaning of the thirty-seven chapters of the sutra.
The intention of birth and death is that birth and death are countless, and the reason for awakening is because the seeds are forgotten.
The original intention was to sit and practice the Way for ten days, but one cannot complete ten days, because the blessings from past lives are meager.
Those with many blessings, if they wish to sit and practice for ten days, will succeed.
The body does not wish to practice because it is weak and emaciated;
The mind does not wish to practice because it does not contemplate death, decay, suffering, and emptiness.
Wisdom has four aspects:
First, having heard good words, one does not turn away;
Second, having listened, one accepts and holds it in the mind;
Third, having held it in the mind, one contemplates it again and again;
Fourth, having contemplated it in the mind, one asks about it again and again, wishing to understand its meaning.
This is lesser wisdom.
There were five hundred people practicing the Way who attained concentration, but fearing they would lose it, they took people to be killed.
The people said:
Killing monks will cause me to receive grave offenses.
The monks said:
It's like a person who has an enemy who wants to kill them;
It's not the body, it's my enemy, you kill it for me.
The Buddha said:
You should kill the mind, not the body.
There was a monk who attained concentration, and at that time a forest fire burned him, but his clothes did not burn.
People saw him and thought he was a ghost, so they chopped at him, but the sword broke and did not penetrate.
Because his mind was focused, he was not burned;
Because he was gentle, he was not penetrated.
There was a monk who attained concentration, and when his disciple called him to eat, he did not respond.
So he pulled his arm forward, and the arm extended to more than ten feet. The disciple was greatly frightened and then tied it up.
The mind was bound and could not be untied, so he took it to be unraveled.
When the master woke up from meditation, he suffered from a painful arm and asked his disciple, who explained as such.
The master said:
If you didn't understand, you mistakenly broke my arm.
When a person attains concentration, they become gentle like cotton, and it is the same in the mother's womb.
There are three causes and conditions for an enlightened person to be ignorant:
First, the question does not match the answer;
Second, one is unable to ask;
Third, one is unable to speak.
To take the essence of the sutra's analogy,
When a person encounters a great flood, they should only take precious treasures with them, just as a person in the world should only take good intentions with them.
What is not contemplated cannot lead to enlightenment.
Why is this?
Because it is not a cause and condition of the Way.
There are causes and conditions of the Way that can lead to enlightenment.
This refers to the six perfections, mindfulness of breathing, and the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment, which are the causes and conditions of the Way.
There are five causes and conditions for trustworthiness:
First, believing in the Buddha;
Second, believing in the Dharma;
Third, believing in the precepts;
Fourth, believing in the sutras;
Fifth, believing in good and wise advisors.
By believing in these five things, one can attain the Way.
There are four aspects to speech:
First, straightforward speech;
Second, discriminating speech;
Third, questioning speech;
Fourth, stopping speech.
Direct speech means speaking directly about the causes and conditions of a wise person falling into the path.
Discriminating speech means that if what is received is not true, one should discriminate the beginning and end and speak it again.
Questioning speech means that if a person thinks something is so, they should ask about the causes and conditions and then they will know for themselves.
Stopping speech means not speaking about what the Buddha has not spoken about.
There are four causes and conditions for asking questions:
First, all questions;
Second, discriminating questions;
Third, questioning questions;
Fourth, stopping questions.
All worldly things are impermanent, suffering, and empty. Practicing the path leads to peace and security. Speaking this is called appropriate speech, and it is called all questions.
If someone asks about the matter of the eyes, do not use the ears to answer. This is called discriminating questions.
If someone brings a white object and says it is a black object, and then brings a black object and asks what it is,
this is a question about a question.
If someone comes and asks what kind of path it is,
one responds based on the cold, what kind of it is;
if one asks what kind of intention it is,
one responds based on the wind, what kind of it is;
if one asks what kind of non-existence it is,
one responds based on emptiness, what kind of it is.
This is a question that is stopped.
There are four inversions:
First, what is impermanent, people think is permanent;
Second, what is suffering, people think is happiness;
Third, all things are empty, people think they are real;
Fourth, what is not a body, they greedily think is a body.
People fall into such inversions, thinking what is impermanent is permanent, what is suffering is happiness, what is empty is real, and what is not a body is a body.
If people have such an intention, they can attain the path.
Because people's minds fall into the four inversions, they think this is their body.
Carefully contemplate that there is nothing in the body;
Since there is nothing, one falls into emptiness;
Having fallen into emptiness, one becomes bodiless;
Being bodiless, one falls into the unconditioned.
People have four kinds of delusion and always cling to four kinds of inverted views:
First, all things are impermanent, yet they consider them to be permanent;
Second, the world is all suffering, yet people take it to be happiness;
Third, the world is empty, yet people take it to be existent;
Fourth, the body is not the body and cannot be preserved, yet people take it to be the body;
Fifth, when the moon is newly born, one bows to it;
Sixth, when it is full on the fifteenth day, one sits cross-legged and looks up at it;
Seventh, when a girl is young, one is held by others;
Eighth, when she grows up, one cannot see her.
There are four honorable things, and there are also four lowly things:
First, the Way is honorable, while people are lowly;
Second, precious treasures are honorable, while people are lowly;
Third, official positions are honorable, while people are lowly;ğŸ”½...
Fourth, the wise are respected, while the foolish are despised.
Ä€nanda said:
If a person obtains a good teacher, it is as if they have obtained half of the Buddha's enlightenment.
The Buddha said:
If a person obtains a good teacher, it is as if they have obtained the Buddha's enlightenment.
Good teachers are difficult to find.
What is meant by morality and virtue?
Faith is the way;
Restraining body, speech, and mind is virtue.
A person should have three kinds of teachers:
First, a wealthy family;
Second, one who serves the noble;
Third, a greatly revered one.
Giving is considered a wealthy family, upholding precepts is considered serving the noble, guarding the mind and contemplating the Way is considered serving the greatly revered one.
There is inner cultivation and outer cultivation:
Seeking money and various precious treasures is considered outer cultivation;
Guarding the mind and contemplating the Way is considered inner cultivation.ğŸ”½If a person cannot subdue their own mind, they want to subdue the minds of others instead;
If one can subdue their own mind, the minds of others can all be subdued.
There is inner power and outer power, inner form and outer form, inner consciousness and outer consciousness.
Being able to control evil thoughts is inner power;
Being able to do things and lift heavy anger is outer power.
Sensation, perception, mental formations, and consciousness are inner form;
Earth, water, fire, wind, and space are outer form.
Mindfulness is inner consciousness, while seeing with the eyes is outer consciousness.
There are four things that are greatly difficult:
First, it is very difficult to meet with those who have attained the Way, referring to the twelve wise ones;
Second, it is difficult to hear the sutra and have it enter the mind, referring to being in the eight difficult situations;
Third, it is difficult to contemplate according to the original teachings, referring to falling into the four inverted views;
Fourth, it is difficult to practice according to the Dharma, referring to being unable to uphold the precepts.
There are five things that are greatly difficult in seeking the Way:
First, old age;
Second, illness;
Third, official duties;ğŸ”½...
Fourth, thieves;
Fifth, hunger and thirst.
These are the five difficulties in seeking the Way.
There are five difficulties:
First, it is difficult to encounter the Buddha's world;
Second, it is difficult to hear the sutra;ğŸ”½Third, it is difficult to find a good teacher;
Fourth, it is difficult to find a good person;
Fifth, it is difficult to become a human being.
There are five difficulties:
First, it is difficult for the poor to be able to give;
Second, it is difficult for the wealthy and noble to be able to endure;
Third, it is difficult for those with affairs to face officials without deceiving;
Fourth, it is difficult for those on the same bed with an upright woman to not be confused;
Fifth, it is difficult to control one's life and not harm others.
There are seven difficulties:
First, it is difficult to receive the sutra and be able to ask about difficulties;
Second, it is difficult to hear the sutra and understand its meaning;
Third, it is difficult to be able to understand oneself when speaking with many wise people;
Fourth, it is difficult to teach oneself and also to be able to teach others;
Fifth, it is difficult to bring peace to oneself and also to bring peace to others;
Sixth, it is difficult to attain mental concentration oneself and also to help others attain mental concentration;
Seventh, it is difficult to never be apart from the Dharma until attaining Buddhahood.
There are eighteen things that are extremely difficult for people in the world:
First, it is difficult to encounter a Buddha in the world;
Second, even if one encounters a Buddha, it is difficult to attain a human body;ğŸ”½Third, even if one attains a human body, it is difficult to be born in a central country;
Fourth, even if one is in a central country, it is difficult to be born into a family of good social standing;
Fifth, even if one is born into a family of good social standing, it is difficult for the four limbs and six senses to be complete;
Sixth, even if the four limbs and six senses are complete, it is difficult to have wealth and property;
Seventh, even if one has wealth and property, it is difficult to have good friends;
Eighth, even if one obtains good spiritual friends, it is difficult to have wisdom;
Ninth, even if one has wisdom, it is difficult to have a cautious mind;
Tenth, even if one has a cautious mind, it is difficult to be able to give;
Eleventh, even if one is able to give, it is difficult to wish to obtain virtuous and virtuous people;
Twelfth, even if one obtains virtuous and virtuous people, it is difficult to go to them;
Thirteenth, even if one goes to them, it is difficult to be suitable;ğŸ”½Fourteenth, even if one is suitable, it is difficult to listen and ask;
Fifteenth, even if one listens and asks, it is difficult to speak loyally and correctly;
Sixteenth, even if one is loyal and correct, it is difficult to understand wisdom;
Seventeenth, even if one understands wisdom, it is difficult to be able to accept profound sutras;
Eighteenth, even if one can understand profound sutras, it is difficult to repeat them.
These are the eighteen difficulties for people in the world.
Are there eight kinds of people whom the Buddha cannot save?
First, mute people;
second, deaf people;ğŸ”½third, people in hell;
fourth, people in the realm of hungry ghosts;
fifth, people in the animal realm;
sixth, people in borderlands who do not know the Dharma and its meaning;
seventh, people who live long lives in the twenty-eight heavens;
eighth, people who receive practices that are not vigorous.
These are the eight kinds of people whom the Buddha cannot save.
Five hundred people said to themselves:
We are good.
The Buddha said:
You should be good and follow me.
The people said:
Yes!
The Buddha then entered the fire, and the five hundred people all stopped and did not dare follow, saying that good people are very difficult to find.
Someone asked the Buddha:
The Buddha teaches people to do good, what are the benefits?
The Buddha said:
I only teach them because the people of the world are troubled.
The people said:
People have minds, they should be allowed to do as they please.
The Buddha said:
It is because people of the world indulge their minds that I have abided for a hundred kalpas before attaining Buddhahood.
The Way has seven things:
First, being delighted to give without wanting anything in return;
Second, only wanting to listen;
Third, only believing;
Fourth, only upholding precepts;
Fifth, only wanting to practice;
Sixth, wanting to study wisdom;
Seventh, only wanting to be liberated.

Those who attain liberation in the Buddha's time, later will only study wisdom; those who only want to practice later, will only uphold precepts later; those who only believe later, will only want to listen later; those who only want to give later, will only be delighted to give later.

Not only should one hear [the Dharma] after giving, but one should also believe [in it] after hearing [the Dharma]; not only should one believe [in it], but one should also uphold the precepts; not only should one uphold the precepts, but one should also practice [the Dharma]; not only should one practice [the Dharma], but one should also cultivate wisdom; not only should one cultivate wisdom, but one should also attain liberation. These seven matters should be practiced together.
There are five kinds of decline:
First, the lifespan of people in the past was long, while the lifespan of people in the present is short;
Second, the appearance of people in the past was upright and rosy, while the appearance of people in the present is ugly;
Third, many people in the past attained the Way, while people in the present cannot attain it;
Fourth, people in the past were knowledgeable and understood the essentials of the scriptures, while people in the present cannot understand them;
Fifth, people in the past were at ease, while people in the present are often sick and emaciated.
These are the five kinds of decline in the world.
There was a long-lived ascetic who was very wealthy, with countless possessions, and enjoyed giving.
Someone said:
You give a lot of alms!
The practitioner replied:
I have heard from the Buddha that people in the world come and go through birth and death, and the days are innumerable.
Now, all the giving I have done, I still cannot use a single coin a day, how can it be considered much?
The Buddha said that people may obtain all the precious treasures in the world, but it is not as good as hearing a single word from the Buddha.
Why is it so?
It is because having many possessions cannot free one from the world.

In the mountains, there is a bird with long feathers on its tail. If the feathers get caught on something, it dares not go any further, loving them for fear of plucking them, and is caught by hunters, sitting there with its body scattered for the sake of a single feather.
People scatter their thoughts on love and affection, and possessions, unable to escape suffering, because of greed and lust.

People make a living, like bees making honey, collecting many flowers, working hard for days, and when it is done, people attack and take it away, and they cannot eat it themselves, only exhausting themselves.
People run east and west, seeking this and doing that, accumulating wealth with untold hardships.
When their lives end, others get their wealth, and they receive heavy punishments and immeasurable suffering.
People in the world are like riding a mud boat across a river, about to sink, the boat is about to break.
The human body is like a mud boat, not lasting long, one should quickly practice the Way.
Gold has four tests:
First, burning;
Second, grinding;ğŸ”½Third, forging;
Fourth, refining.
Metaphorically, people also have four tests:
First, teasing;
Second, engaging together;
Third, appearance;
Fourth, not stopping when restricted.
To know a person, there are four conditions - first, living together;
Second, living together for a long time;
Third, having conversations together;
Fourth, working together - then one can know them.
There are four conditions by which one knows they are a practitioner:
First, hearing evil that disturbs the mind, one immediately turns to contemplation;
Second, not speaking of others' faults;
Third, not engaging in debates oneself;
Fourth, being able to protect oneself.
Thus, one knows they are a practitioner who protects themselves.
In this world, there are four conditions for receiving blessings:
First, having a place;
Second, having the right time;
Third, karma;
Fourth, a teacher.
If a person has a place to stay, they can attain peace and contentment, which is having a place.
If a person should become wealthy at age thirty, seeking it at fifteen will not succeed, but at thirty they will attain it, which is having the right time.
If a person is suitable for trading white pearls or other things, and they gain profit from it, this is karma.
Encountering a wise person who explains the sutras, and one's mind is immediately enlightened, this is having a teacher.
They had three brothers, each thinking themselves the most capable, and they took turns staying up at night. The two older brothers slept in front, and the younger brother sat alone.
There was an insect named unlucky that came and bit his thigh.
The younger brother pointed at it with his finger, and the insect grew larger. He hit it again and it grew even larger.
The man became angry, grabbed the insect, and stomped on it, exhausting himself, but the insect grew even larger and did not stop. He then stopped.

After one night, he called the middle brother to get up, and the insect bit him again. The brother also fought with it like the younger brother, and the insect grew even larger to the size of the house. In this way, he became exhausted and stopped again.
After two nights, he called the older brother to get up and sit. The insect bit him again.

The older brother then held his finger and stroked it, and the insect rose again. The brother thought to cover it with his testicles, and in a moment, it became extremely large and the insect came out of his testicles.
The next day, the two younger brothers were completely unable to get up. The elder brother knew that the two younger brothers had been fighting with insects, so he asked:
Why can't you get up?
The two younger brothers were ashamed and did not dare to speak.
The elder brother said:
Did you fight with insects until you were exhausted?
The younger brothers said:
Yes!
The elder brother told his younger brothers:
If there are any inauspicious insects coming later, just cover them with your bowl, do not use your fingers!
It is like a foolish person who gets angry when confronted and commits offenses.
It is like the younger brothers fighting with insects, exhausting themselves.
A wise person, when confronted, avoids it, and gains blessings, like covering an inauspicious insect with a bowl.
In the past, there was a monk who expounded the sutra for the king.
The king said:
When the Buddha was in the world, many people attained the Way.
Now, expounding the Buddha's sutra, people do not attain the Way.
Did the Buddha take the Dharma of the Way with him?
The monk said:

It is like the most delicious wine in the world. If one drinks one sheng, one will become intoxicated. If one takes one sheng of water and mixes it with one sheng of wine, one cannot become intoxicated by drinking it.
When the Buddha was in the world, he expounded the sutras, knowing people's dispositions. It is like a person who drinks one sheng of wine and becomes intoxicated. Now we do not know this.
The Buddha expounded the sutras, knowing people's dispositions, and gave medicine according to the illness, so many people attained the Way.

There was a king who offered food to the bhikshus. The gods came and pointed out to the king, saying, This person has attained arhatship, this person is a bodhisattva, this person has attained the Way, and this person does not uphold the precepts.
The king fully understood and held his mind in proper balance, without any different thoughts. The gods rejoiced on his behalf.
There was a king who competed with others to offer a high price to bathe the Buddha. The king kept raising the price without stopping.
The others said:
Now I will use all my wealth, my wife and children, and myself as slaves to bathe the Buddha.
The king then could not get it.

When King AÅ›oka was about to die, there were five hundred bodhisattvas and arhats who guarded him together, expounded the sÅ«tras for him, and did not allow the consorts to approach and see him, wanting to make the king ascend to heaven.
There was a small king who always rose up to attack.
The great king thought to himself, saying:
Losing one's body and incurring evil are all due to greed and love.
I might as well give the country to him!
The great king abandoned the country and left, becoming a layman in another country. After a long time, he returned to his former country.
Someone reported to him, and he ordered his attendants to go capture and kill him.
When he was about to die, he called his son and entrusted him with a single word:
Be careful not to forget!
Do not think of your enemy, but must have a compassionate mind!
There was a king whose governance was not impartial, who oppressed the people, accepted bribes, and the heavens did not rain in a timely manner.
A woman said:
It is because the king's governance is not just and fair.

The king heard this and summoned the woman to pray for rain. He placed three vessels on the ground. The woman prayed for the rain to fall in the middle vessel, and then to start from one end. It was just as she wished.
The king asked:
What is the reason for this?
The woman said:
It is because of my sincerity.
The Buddha said:
Where there is earth, there are myriad things. Where there is sincerity, there is the Way.
Once a king went out and saw a woman who was incomparably beautiful. The king wanted to kill her husband and take her as his own.
The ministers said:
He should not be killed, but enjoyed.
The king then honored her husband with a golden ring, saying:
If you forget the ring, you will be killed!
The king secretly called the woman and told her to steal the ring.
Later, the king called and asked the husband where the ring was. The husband did not know where it was, so the king ordered a minister to kill him.
The king ordered delicious food and drink, but the husband was afraid and did not dare to eat.
People said:
You are about to die, why don't you eat?
The husband wanted to eat fish, and he found the ring in the belly of the fish. This was due to his utmost sincerity.
There was a poor monk who raised 100,000 to use for his livelihood.
He first gave away 30,000 in alms and took the remaining money to do business.
On the way, he was robbed by bandits, and the king then gave him precious treasures.
There were large and small bags. The others each took the large bags and left. The monk thought to himself:
I have little money, so I should not take the large bag.
He then took the small bag and left.
Inside it were all white pearls, which he sold for 6 million.
Because of his utmost sincerity and lack of greed, he obtained these precious treasures.
In the past, a king summoned the blind people of the country to observe an elephant in the elephant stable.
Some held the elephant's foot, some held the elephant's trunk, some held the elephant's ear, and some held the elephant's tail.
After leaving, they asked each other:
What is an elephant like?
The one who held the elephant's foot said:
An elephant is as big as a pillar.
The one who held the elephant's trunk said:
An elephant is like a rope.
The one who held the elephant's ear said:
An elephant is like a winnowing fan.
The one who held the elephant's tail said:
An elephant is like a large stick.
They all argued, each blind person confident in their own opinion.
It is like people who each see a small part of the scriptures, do not understand the Dharma, and think they have great understanding, it is the same as this.
There was a king who held a grand feast outside the city, and all the people of the country went out to watch.
In the city, there was a family. The father had an illness and could not walk. The family members helped him and wanted to take him out, saying:
Stop when we leave the city.
Under the tree, he could not reach by himself. He told the family members:
You go and look, and then bring me back.
At that time, Åšakra, Lord of the Devas, transformed into a monk who passed by his side and called out to the sick person:
Follow me, and I can cure your illness.
Hearing this, the person was overjoyed and immediately got up and followed him.
Åšakra brought him up to heaven to his palace. Seeing the abundant gold, silver, and fine objects, he wanted to ask for them.
The person said:
Do not do that. You can ask for a begging bowl.
The sick person then went to where Åšakra was and said:
I want to leave. Please give me this bowl as alms.
Åšakra immediately gave it to him and said to the sick person:
There are things inside that you wish for.
The sick person took it home, and the family members gathered to open it. They found the gold, silver, and precious treasures they had wished for, and they all obtained them to their heart's content.
The relatives and clansmen gathered for a great feast, and they enjoyed themselves together.
After they were all drunk and full, they took the bottle and jumped with it, saying:
